raw_text:
2004: An Irish Athletics Year
 
 2004 won't be remembered as one of Irish athletics' great years.
 
 The year began with that optimism which invariably and unaccountably, seems to herald an upcoming Olympiad. But come late August, a few hot days in the magnificent stadium in Athens told us of the true strength of Irish athletics - or to be more accurate, the lack of it. Sonia O'Sullivan's Olympic farewell apart, there was little to stir the emotions of Irish athletics watchers. But after the disastrous build-up to the games, we shouldn't have been surprised. At the start of the year, an O'Sullivan had been earmarked as Ireland's best medal prospect but as it turned out, walker Gillian never even made it to the start line because of injury. Less than a week before the Olympics, the sport was rocked by news that 10,000m hope Cathal Lombard had tested for the banned substance EPO. Lombard's shattering of Mark Carroll's national 10,000m record in April had already set tongues wagging but even the most cynical of observers, were surprised when he was rumbled after an Irish Sports Council sting operation. The Corkman quickly held his hands up in admission and was promptly handed a two-year ban from the sport.
 
 Back at pre-Olympic ranch in Greece, it must have seemed that things couldn't have got any worse but they very nearly did with walker Jamie Costin lucky to escape with his life after being involved in a car crash near Athens. Once the track and field action began in Athens, a familiar pattern of underachievement emerged although Alistair Cragg's performance in being the only athlete from a European nation to qualify for the 5,000m final did offer hope for the future. Our beloved Sonia scraped into the women's 5K final as a fastest loser and for a couple of days, the country attempted to delude itself into believing that she might be in the medal shake-up. As it happened, she went out the back door early in the final although there was nothing undignified about the way that she insisted on finishing the race over a minute behind winner Meseret Defar. It later transpired that Sonia had been suffering from a stomach bug in the 48 hours before the final although typically, the Cobhwoman played down the effects of the illness. Amazingly, she was back in action a couple of weeks later when beating a world-class field at the Flora Lite 5K road race in London and while her major championship days may be over, it's unlikely that we have seen the last of her in competition. At least Sonia managed to make it to Athens. At the start of the year, several Northern Ireland athletes had genuine hopes of qualifying for the Games but come August, an out-of-form and injured Paul Brizzel was the lone standard bearer for the province. The Ballymena man gave it a lash but his achilles problem, and a bad lane draw, meant a time of 21.00 and an early exit.
 
 James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, Zoe Brown and Paul McKee all had to be content with watching the Athens action on their television screens. 800m hope McIlroy never got near his best during the summer and a fourth place in the British trials effectively ended his hopes of making the plane. The injury-plagued Turnbull gamely travelled round Europe in search of the 1500m qualifying mark but 3:39 was the best he could achieve, after missing several months training during the previous winter. A lingering hamstring probem and a virus wrecked McKee's Athens ambitions and both he and Turnbull deserve a slice of better fortune in 2005. Pole vaulter Brown had hoped for a vote of confidence from the British selectors after she had achieved the Athens B standard but the call never came. As the summer ended, stalwarts Catherina McKiernan and Dermot Donnelly hung up their competitive spikes. McKiernan had to candidly acknowledge that time had crept up on her after several injury-ravaged years. Donnelly and his Annadale Striders team-mates later suffered tragedy when their friend and clubman Andy Campbell was found dead at his home on 18 December. A large turnout of athletics-loving folk turned out in west Belfast to offer their respects to the Campbell family and Andy's many friends. As only death can, it put the year's athletics happenings in a sharp perspective.
llama3.2:1b:
2004: An Irish Athletics Year

The year began with optimism for Irish athletics, but was marred by a series of setbacks including Sonia O'Sullivan's Olympic farewell, walker Gillian Lombard's banned substance scandal, and Jamie Costin's car crash.

Walker Jill Kirkwood and Paul Brizzel were notable athletes who struggled through the season due to injury and poor performances. Despite hoping for medals, they ultimately failed to achieve them.

Northern Ireland athletes performed reasonably well but not enough to qualify for the Games, with several losing out on selection. James McIlroy, Zoe Brown, Paul McKee, and Gareth Turnbull all had limited success in their respective events.

The year also saw the passing of stalwarts Catherina McKiernan and Dermot Donnelly.
llama3.2:3b: 2004 Irish Athletics Year: The country did not have a great year at the Olympics, with most athletes underachieving or failing to qualify due to injuries, suspensions, and poor form. Notable exceptions included Sonia O'Sullivan's performance in the 5K final and Alistair Cragg's qualification for the 5000m final. The year also saw the end of careers for several athletes, including Catherina McKiernan and Dermot Donnelly.
gemma2:2b:
2004 was an underwhelming year for Irish athletics, marked by disappointment and injury setbacks. While Sonia O'Sullivan made her farewell at the Olympics, other athletes failed to perform, leaving Ireland short of medalists. 
Cathal Lombard's doping scandal was a major blow to Irish athletics, followed by injuries and crashes affecting other athletes' participation in the Olympics. Despite this, Alistair Cragg performed well in the 5000m final, with Sonia O'Sullivan ultimately making a respectable showing at the women's 5k race.  Several Northern Ireland athletes failed to qualify for the Olympics due to various injuries and form struggles. James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, Zoe Brown and Paul McKee were unable to compete in Athens, while pole vaulter Brown was left disappointed after missing out on a potential selection opportunity. The year also marked the end of Catherina McKiernan's competitive career and the tragic passing of Andy Campbell, highlighting the human side of athletic competition and loss.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
The text discusses Ireland's recent athletics performance during the 2004 Irish Athletics Year, which ended with disappointing results for several athletes. The key points are:

1. Athens Games: In August, Ireland's top athletes, Sonia O'Sullivan and Jamie Costin, missed out on Olympic medals after injury.

2. O'Sullivan injury: While O'Sullivan made the Athens Olympics, she suffered a stomach bug that sidelined her in the final weeks of competition.

3. Turnbull injury: The injured Turnbull struggled to qualify for the 1500m national trials, finishing just outside the top five, and his performance was overshadowed by his hamstring issue and virus infection.

4. McKee and Donnelly: Both McKee and Donnelly suffered from injuries that affected their performances in the Athens Games.

5. Campbell tragedy: Andy Campbell, a friend of McKiernan's team, died in December while he attended an event in west Belfast. 

6. Timely response: The text suggests that athletes who were injured or suffering with serious health issues may not have been able to make it back home for the Olympics.
qwen2.5:1.5b: 2004 was not remembered as one of Ireland's great athletic years due to poor performance, doping scandal involving Cathal Lombard, injuries to athletes, and absence of major medal prospects.
qwen2.5:3b: 2004 was not remembered as an outstanding year for Irish athletics, marked by underachievement and setbacks. Sonia O'Sullivan retired after her Olympic performances, with Gillian Walker failing to qualify for the Athens Olympics due to injury. The country was further shaken when Cathal Lombard tested positive for EPO before the Games. While Alistair Cragg qualified for the 5000m final, the rest of the team struggled; Sonia O'Sullivan's performance in Athens was poor, and Paul Brizzel failed to qualify from Northern Ireland. James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, Zoe Brown, and Paul McKee were unable to participate due to injuries or other issues. The year concluded with athletes like Catherina McKiernan and Dermot Donnelly retiring. Andy Campbell's death highlighted the significance of these athletic events.

<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the 2004 Irish Athletics Year. The user wants a concise summary that preserves key ideas and details. Let me read through the provided text carefully.

First, the year started with optimism, but there were major issues. They mention a few hot days in the stadium but don't stir emotions. There was an injury problem with Gillian, who didn't make it to the start. Also, Cathal Lombard's race was banned, which made people shock. Corkman got a two-year ban.

At pre-Olympic ranch, Jamie Costin escaped and got a life. Sonia's 5K performance is mentioned; she finished second. She had an illness but recovered. Meanwhile, Paul Brizzel from Northern Ireland didn't qualify, leaving hope in check for the rest of the year. James McIlroy and others missed the Olympics.

Gareth Turnbull was searching for qualifying marks with a long time off. Paul McKee couldn't make it to Athens due to injury. Brown aimed for confidence but failed. Andy Campbell died, adding tragedy. The events were overhyped until December 18 when Andy's family showed up.

I need to capture all the main points: key athletes, incidents, lack of progress in sports, and the tragic end with a shift in focus.

Now, I'll structure this into a concise summary without explanations or formatting.
</think>

2004: The Irish Athletics Year began with optimism, but major issues arose. Despite hot weather in the stadium, emotions didn't stir as injuries to Gillian and Lombard left athletes struggling. Paul Brizzel's injury, along with an illness affecting Sonia, halted progress. Corkman received a two-year ban for his car crash. Jamie Costin escaped with a life, while Andy Campbell's death highlighted the year's tragedy. Key athletes like James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, and Paul McKee missed the Olympics, but Paul Brizzel's injury and Andy Campbell's tragic end left hope in doubt. The 2005 season will see changes, especially as Andy's family showed support for December's death.
tinyllama:1.1b: In 2004, Irish athletics saw no significant improvements over previous years with disappointing results in both the Olympics and national championships. In the lead-up to the games, O'Suillivan, the country's top hope for the women's 10,000m, suffered a devastating injury that resulted in her being forced to pull out of the Olympics. The Irish Sports Council sting operation also revealed the presence of the banned substance EPO in Cathal Lombard's system, which led to Lombard's suspension and a two-year ban from the sport. Despite these challenges, Sonia Costin managed to qualify for the women's 5,000m final but ultimately finished out of contention due to a fastest-loser performance. Northern Ireland athletes James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, and Zoë Brown were all out of action in the summer, while Paul McKee also failed to reach the podium during the British trials. In 2005, Irish athletics saw promising performances at both the Olympics and national championships, but they ended on a sad note with the death of former teammate Andy Campbell. Despite this setback, the year had its share of highlights for the country, including Catherina McKiernan's retirement after a long career in athletics, Dermot Donnelly's friend and clubmate's tragic end, and the outstanding performances of Sonia Costin in qualifying for the women's 5K final at the Flora Lité road race.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Despite having ended an Olympic year with a disappointing absence of major Irish athletes, this report offers an insight into the Irish athletics landscape from the perspective of a dedicated sports writer—Dolphin. The text covers various aspects such as the rising star of 2004, Sonia O'Sullivan, the disastrous build-up to the Athens Olympics, and the impact of a series of unfortunate events on Irish athletics. Moreover, it highlights the absence of some key athletes like James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, Zoe Brown, and Paul McKee who could have made significant contributions to the medals tally in Athens. Despite these setbacks, the year did not mark a total loss for Irish athletics as some of the key athletes still managed to qualify for the final stages of their respective events. Nevertheless, it was clear that a strong performance in the future would be required for Irish athletics to achieve its full potential at the major championships and other international competitions.
phi:2.7b: In 2004, Irish athletics did not have many standout performances. The main highlight was Sonia O'Sullivan's Olympic farewell, although she had been earmarked as Ireland's best medal prospect. However, just before the games, it was discovered that 10,000m hopefuls Cathal Lombard and Mark Carroll were both taking banned substances. Lombard tested positive for EPO after breaking Mark Carroll's national record in April. He quickly admitted to his mistake and received a two-year ban from the sport. Meanwhile, walker Jamie Costin survived an accident near Athens but couldn't participate in the event due to an injury. The only athlete from Europe to qualify for the 5,000m final was Alistair Cragg, who brought some hope for the future of Irish athletics. However, Sonia O'Sullivan's performance was not as great as expected, and she could only finish in fourth place. At the start of the year, Northern Ireland had several athletes qualified for the Games, but they all failed to qualify due to injuries or other reasons. The summer ended with the retirement of stalwarts Catherina McKiernan and Dermot Donnelly. They were followed by the tragic death of clubman Andy Campbell in December.
orca-mini:3b: 2004 was not a great year for Irish athletics. Although there were some notable performances such as Alistair Cragg's qualification for the 5,000m final and Sonia O'Sullivan's Olympic farewell, there was little to inspire confidence in the rest of the year. Sonia tested positive for EPO which shocked the sporting world, and she was banned from the sport for two years. Jamie Costin survived a car accident but walked away with a lucky escape. 800m hopeful McIlroy struggled to qualify for the Olympics and Gareth Turnbull missed the qualifying mark in the 1500m race. Pole vaulter Brown faced challenges with her training and did not make it to the Olympics. Catherina McKiernan and Dermot Donnelly retired from competitive athletics. Andy Campbell, a friend and team-mate of theirs, passed away due to an illness.
hermes3:3b:
2004 Irish Athletics Year summary:
- Disastrous year for Irish athletics
- Sonia O'Sullivan as lone medal prospect
- Injuries, doping scandals & underachievement
  - Gillian walker & Cathal Lombard
  - Jamie Costin car crash
  - Alistair Cragg's only European qualifier
  - Sonia O'Sullivan's performance
stablelm-zephyr:3b: In 2004, Irish athletics had a relatively underwhelming year. Sonia O'Sullivan's Olympic farewell and walker Gillian's injury before the Olympics highlighted setbacks. Walkers Jamie Costin and Paul Brizzel struggled to perform, while 800m hopeful James McIlroy and other athletes like Gareth Turnbull, Zoe Brown, and Paul McKee missed out on medals or qualification. The year ended with several athletes retiring, including Catherina McKiernan and Dermot Donnelly, and the tragic loss of Andy Campbell.
stablelm2:1.6b:
In 2004, Irish athletics faced challenges as few athletes achieved success at the Olympic Games despite early optimism. Gillian MacPherson's injury caused her to miss the Olympics and Cathal Lombard tested for banned substance EPO which resulted in a two-year ban. Jamie Costin narrowly escaped death in a car crash before competing in Athens. Sonia O'Sullivan made it to the women's 5K final but fell short of the medal round due to a stomach bug. Northern Ireland athletes had high hopes for qualification, but Paul Brizzel finished early due to an achilles injury and bad lane draw. James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, Zoe Brown, and Paul McKee did not achieve their Olympic dreams, but were content with watching from afar.

In the end, 2004 reminded us that Irish athletics needed a strong performance at the Games to be remembered as one of Ireland's great years.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
2004 was not a standout year for Irish athletics. Sonia O'Sullivan, initially touted as Ireland's top medal hope, faced personal issues and an injury that prevented her from competing in the 1000m at the Olympics in Athens. Her performance was subpar due to a stomach bug, but she demonstrated resilience by winning the Flora Lite 5K road race two weeks later.

Other Irish athletes faced setbacks: Paul Brizzel, a Northern Ireland hopeful, struggled with an achilles injury and poor lane placement in the Olympic 800m; James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, Zoe Brown, and Paul McKee did not qualify for the event. Pole vaulter Zoe Brown missed a chance to secure her spot due to the British selectors' decision.

Catherina McKiernan retired from competitive athletics after years of injury, while Dermot Donnelly's friend Andy Campbell tragically passed away, causing the community to reflect on the year's events in a poignant way. The year began with optimism but ended in disappointment for Irish athletes at the Olympic Games.
chatgpt-4o-latest: 2004 was a disappointing year for Irish athletics, culminating in underwhelming performances at the Athens Olympics. Hopes were high early in the year, but setbacks, including injuries and doping scandals, dampened expectations. Gillian O'Sullivan, once a medal prospect, missed the Games due to injury, while Cathal Lombard was banned for using EPO. Jamie Costin survived a serious car crash before the Olympics. On the track, Alistair Cragg's 5,000m final qualification was a rare highlight, while Sonia O'Sullivan, battling illness, finished far behind in her final Olympic race but later won a road race in London. Northern Irish athletes struggled, with Paul Brizzel the only qualifier, while others like James McIlroy, Gareth Turnbull, Zoe Brown, and Paul McKee failed to make the team due to injuries or poor form. The year also saw the retirements of Catherina McKiernan and Dermot Donnelly, and ended on a somber note with the death of athlete Andy Campbell, reminding the community of life's greater realities.
